awd_titl_txt: Enabling Research for the Next Generation GW Detectors
awd_abstract_narration:
Advanced LIGO transformed gravitation, astrophysics and cosmology by opening the gravitational- wave window on the universe, establishing a new paradigm for multimessenger observations. The scientific case for constructing a network of 3rd generation ground based interferometric gravitational wave detectors with about a factor 10X sensitivity improvement is compelling. The detectors would observe all the compact binary coalescences in the universe and bring the new field into cosmological research. The most realistic way to improve the detectors is by increasing the length of the interferometer arms as the gravitational wave signals grow with the length while most of the significant limiting noise is independent of, or varies slowly, with the length. A significant fraction of cost of the detectors will be in the ultra-high vacuum (UHV) system needed for the beam tubes and the civil work in preparing the site. The group proposes to explore a range of concepts in vacuum technology that could reduce the cost of UHV tube systems by a factor of about 2X, amounting to a saving of $200M to $300M in a 3rd generation detector. 

The program will explore novel techniques to economically fabricate vacuum systems using and building on the latest metallurgical and materials science innovations. The investigations will be conducted in collaboration with the DOE (FNAL) and an international partner (CERN). Successfully identifying novel fabrication approaches and beam tube designs will have applicability beyond the immediate interests of gravitational wave astrophysics. Next generation high energy colliders that dwarf the LHC will also need innovative concepts for their vacuum infrastructure. The applicability of the material coatings research that will be explored also promises to have an economic impact in the use of coated steels for various industrial applications. The initiative here, to enable the construction of 3rd generation detectors, will generate new opportunities to attract, inspire and educate future scientists, citizens and leaders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project had three major outcomes.

1. Demonstration of a vacuum accident recovery approach using ultra-dry filtered air to limit the amount of water vapor reabsorbed into the vacuum system. The LIGO Tube Recovery Experiment (LTREX) used a residual 7m section of LIGO 304L stainless steel tube as a testbed. It was modified to form a large vacuum chamber with the addition of two end caps. LTREX was baked for 30 days at 150C to remove the water adsorbed onto the inner surfaces. Repeated vents using ultra-high purity air in cylinders passed through a dessicating filter (Entegris XCDA®) ensured that the vented LTREX was only exposed to parts per billion (ppb) levels of water vapor. Indeed, a subsequent pump down successfully demonstrated the goals of this investigation, namely rapid recovery to residual water vapor pressure of ~10-9 Torr in only a few days of pumping and without needing another high-temperature bakeout.

Impact: This result informs future approaches to venting and recovering large ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) systems. This applies to the current operational 2nd generation interferometric gravitational wave detectors, as well as planned much longer 3rd generation instruments.

2. Exploration of surface preparations for mild carbon steel to reduce the water binding energy and thus to permit a lower-temperature bakeout. Working with the company SilcoTek©, we first explored hydrophobic silicon coatings used in the chip manufacturing industry. We determined that the coating process leaves an unacceptable level of silicon dust on the coated surface, leading to particulate shedding. The technique may prove useful to coat smaller components in test mass vacuum chambers but would not be suitable for coating many kilometers of 1+m diameter beam tubes. A second investigation determined that magnetite (Fe3O4) coating of the steel surface may prove feasible on large scales to protect the mild carbon steel inner surfaces from ferric oxide (Fe2O3) formation. Analyses indicated that the current industrially available processes using either superheated steam introduced onto a room temperature steel surface or water sprayed onto a heated steel surface lead to thick and relatively porous surface layer of magnetite. Further development with industry would be needed to come up with an acceptably thin (<1 µm) and uniform layer.

Impact: The latter finding identified a viable approach to protecting mild steel surfaces for use in large vacuum vessels using magnetite coatings on mild steel. This represents a paradigm shift in how UHV systems may be more economically fabricated using non-stainless steel materials.

3. Investigation of commercial sources to prototype a movable inductive ring heater to provide a moving, localized outgassing system for in-situ H2O removal. We successfully identified a firm with which we worked to design and procure a prototype induction heating system that will be used in the coming year to heat a sub-scale beam tube prototype (6.1 m long x 10cm diameter) mild steel pipe. This experiment will assess the feasibility of a zonally-restricted moving bakeout versus a traditional bakeout which brings the entire tube to high temperature at one time. This effort included developing an isotherm model of the water outgassing, both updating and improving the model developed for initial LIGO.

Impact: A demonstration of a sectional bakeout is key to how one can approach the bakeout of systems that are 10X the scale of the initial LIGO interferometers. The then-novel approach used for LIGO of using the beamtube itself as the resistive element in the 150C month-long bakeout will not scale easily to 40 km long beamtubes.

This project has led to a very close collaboration with the CERN Vacuum, Surfaces and Coatings Group. They are developing a prototype demonstration beam tube for the ET project in Europe and this project has profited from frequent technical interchange meetings with CERN colleagues.
